title: قانون رقم 151 لسنة 2020 بشأن حماية البيانات الشخصية
title_en: Personal Data Protection Law No. 151 of 2020
description: Egypt's Personal Data Protection Law No. 151 of 2020, promulgated by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, is the first comprehensive personal data protection legislation in Egypt. It establishes the rights of data subjects, the obligations of data controllers and processors, restrictions on cross-border data transfers, and creates the Personal Data Protection Centre (PDPC) under the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology as the supervisory authority.

provisions.title: Article 1. Definitions
provisions.content: In the application of the provisions of this Law, the following terms shall have the meanings assigned thereto: 'Personal Data' means any data related to a specific natural person or a person who can be identified, directly or indirectly, through identification information such as name, voice, picture, identification number, electronic identifier, location data, or other distinguishing characteristics related to the physical, physiological, economic, cultural, or social identity of that person; 'Sensitive Personal Data' means personal data that reveals racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, as well as genetic data, biometric data, health data, and data concerning a natural person's sex life or sexual orientation, and data related to criminal convictions; 'Processing' means any operation or set of operations performed on personal data, whether or not by automated means, including collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction; 'Controller' means any natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data; 'Processor' means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.

provisions.title: Article 2. Scope of Application
provisions.content: The provisions of this Law shall apply to: (1) personal data processing operations performed, in whole or in part, in the Arab Republic of Egypt; (2) personal data processing operations performed by a controller or processor outside Egypt where the processing relates to: (a) monitoring the behaviour of natural persons residing in Egypt; (b) offering goods or services to persons residing in Egypt. The provisions of this Law shall not apply to: (1) personal data processed by natural persons for personal or household activities not related to commercial, professional or public activity; (2) processing carried out solely for national security purposes or in the interest of defence and public security; (3) deceased persons' data, unless it relates to a living person's rights; (4) statistical and scientific research data managed in an anonymised manner. Processing by security agencies and law enforcement bodies for criminal investigation and prosecution purposes shall be conducted in accordance with a separate legislative framework.

provisions.title: Article 3. Lawful Bases for Processing
provisions.content: Processing of personal data shall be lawful if one or more of the following conditions are satisfied: (1) the data subject has given clear and unambiguous consent to the processing for specified purposes; (2) processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party, or to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract; (3) processing is necessary to comply with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject under Egyptian law; (4) processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or another natural person who is unable to provide consent; (5) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller; (6) processing is necessary for the purposes of legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests of the data subject.

provisions.title: Article 4. Principles of Personal Data Processing
provisions.content: All processing of personal data shall comply with the following principles: (1) Lawfulness and transparency — personal data shall be processed lawfully and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subject; (2) Purpose specification and limitation — personal data shall be collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a manner incompatible with those purposes; (3) Data minimisation — personal data shall be limited to what is necessary for the specified purpose; (4) Accuracy — personal data shall be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date; (5) Storage limitation — personal data shall not be kept in a form that identifies data subjects for longer than necessary; (6) Security — personal data shall be processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security, including protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing, accidental loss, destruction or damage; (7) Accountability — the controller shall be responsible for and able to demonstrate compliance with these principles.

provisions.title: Article 5. Sensitive Personal Data
provisions.content: The processing of sensitive personal data is prohibited except in the following cases: (1) when the data subject has given explicit consent to the processing; (2) when processing is necessary to fulfil obligations in the field of employment and social protection law; (3) when processing is necessary to protect the vital interests of the data subject or another person where the data subject is incapable of giving consent; (4) when processing relates to personal data which are manifestly made public by the data subject; (5) when processing is necessary for medical diagnosis, treatment or healthcare management by medical professionals bound by professional secrecy; (6) when processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest; (7) when processing is required for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims. The controller processing sensitive personal data shall implement enhanced security measures and document the applicable legal basis.

provisions.title: Article 6. Rights of Data Subjects
provisions.content: Data subjects shall have the following rights: (1) the right to be informed — to receive clear information about the processing of their data, including the purposes, legal basis, retention period, and the identity of the controller; (2) the right of access — to obtain a copy of the personal data being processed; (3) the right of rectification — to have inaccurate personal data corrected; (4) the right of erasure — to request deletion of personal data where it is no longer necessary for the purpose it was collected, or where consent is withdrawn; (5) the right to restriction of processing; (6) the right to object to processing based on legitimate interests; (7) the right to data portability — to receive data in a machine-readable format; (8) the right not to be subject to automated decisions. Controllers shall respond to data subject requests within 30 days. The PDPC may extend this period to 60 days for complex cases.

provisions.title: Article 7. Obligations of Controllers
provisions.content: Controllers shall: (1) implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure personal data is processed in compliance with this Law; (2) appoint a data protection officer (DPO) where required under the implementing regulations; (3) conduct a data protection impact assessment before processing that is likely to result in high risk to data subjects; (4) maintain records of processing activities; (5) notify the PDPC and affected data subjects of personal data breaches within 72 hours of becoming aware; (6) implement privacy by design and privacy by default principles; (7) ensure that processors are bound by appropriate contractual obligations; (8) implement appropriate measures when processing sensitive personal data; (9) ensure that any transfer of personal data outside Egypt complies with Article 9 of this Law.

provisions.title: Article 8. Personal Data Protection Centre (PDPC)
provisions.content: A Personal Data Protection Centre (PDPC) shall be established as an independent regulatory body with legal personality and financial and administrative independence, affiliated with the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology. The PDPC shall: (1) monitor and enforce compliance with this Law; (2) issue implementing regulations, guidelines and binding decisions; (3) receive and process data subject complaints; (4) conduct investigations and inspections of controllers and processors; (5) impose administrative sanctions for violations; (6) cooperate with data protection authorities of other states; (7) promote awareness of data protection rights and obligations. The Board of the PDPC shall be composed of members with expertise in law, information technology, and security appointed by the President of the Republic. The PDPC shall publish annual reports on its activities and enforcement actions.

provisions.title: Article 9. Cross-Border Data Transfers
provisions.content: Personal data may only be transferred outside Egypt under the following conditions: (1) the country of destination provides an adequate level of data protection as determined by the PDPC; (2) the data subject has given explicit consent; (3) the transfer is covered by standard contractual clauses approved by the PDPC; (4) binding corporate rules have been approved by the PDPC; (5) the transfer is necessary for the performance of a contract between the data subject and the controller; (6) the transfer is necessary to protect the vital interests of the data subject. Controllers shall document all cross-border transfers. Transfers of sensitive personal data outside Egypt require explicit approval from the PDPC. The PDPC shall publish and maintain a list of countries deemed to provide adequate protection.

provisions.title: Article 10. Penalties
provisions.content: Violations of this Law shall be subject to the following penalties: (1) processing personal data without a legal basis or without the consent required — a fine not less than EGP 100,000 and not exceeding EGP 1,000,000 per violation, doubled upon repetition; (2) processing sensitive personal data in violation of this Law — imprisonment for a period not less than three months and a fine not less than EGP 500,000 and not exceeding EGP 2,000,000; (3) transfer of personal data outside Egypt in violation of this Law — a fine not less than EGP 500,000 and not exceeding EGP 5,000,000; (4) failure to notify the PDPC of a personal data breach — a fine not less than EGP 50,000 and not exceeding EGP 500,000; (5) obstruction of PDPC investigations — imprisonment not exceeding one year and a fine not less than EGP 100,000. Legal persons shall be subject to fines equal to twice those applicable to natural persons.

provisions.title: Article 11. Data Security Requirements
provisions.content: Controllers and processors shall implement the following data security measures proportionate to the risk: (1) pseudonymisation and encryption of personal data; (2) access controls ensuring that only authorised personnel can access personal data on a need-to-know basis; (3) systems and procedures to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of processing systems; (4) procedures for restoring access to personal data in the event of an incident; (5) regular testing and evaluation of the effectiveness of security measures. The PDPC shall issue technical standards specifying minimum security requirements for personal data processing, taking into account internationally recognised standards such as ISO/IEC 27001. In the event of a breach resulting in accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, or unauthorised access to personal data, the controller shall: notify the PDPC within 72 hours; communicate the breach to affected data subjects where the risk is high; take immediate steps to contain and remediate the breach.
